{{Infobox officeholder |name = Henry Keizer |image = Henry Keizer.jpg |imagesize = 250px |caption = Henry Keizer in 2014 |office = [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy#Leadership|Chairman of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] |term_start = 14 June 2014 |term_end = 18 May 2017 |leader = [[Mark Rutte]] |predecessor = [[Benk Korthals]] |successor = [[Incumbent]] |birthname = J.M.H.J. Keizer |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|11|04|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Netherlands|Dutch]] |party = [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] (from 1983) |spouse = |children = 1 son (born 1991) |residence = [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]] |alma_mater = |occupation = [[Businessperson|Businessman]]
[[Board of directors|Corporate director]] |religion = |signature = |website = }} '''Judicus Marinus Henricus Jacobus "Henry" Keizer''' (born 4 November 1960) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] businessman and a former [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy#Leadership|Chairman of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]], the leading political party in the Netherlands.{{nl icon}} [http://nos.nl/artikel/661072-henry-keizer-nieuwe-vvdvoorzitter.html Henry Keizer nieuwe VVD-voorzitter], NOS, 14 June 2014{{nl icon}} [http://www.elsevier.nl/Politiek/nieuws/2014/6/Henry-Keizer-gekozen-als-nieuwe-partijvoorzitter-VVD-1542119W/ Henry Keizer gekozen als nieuwe partijvoorzitter VVD], Elsevier, 14 June 2014 Keizer was elected on 14 June 2014. On 26 May 2015, Keizer stated that the Netherlands should introduce an [[Election threshold|electoral threshold]].{{nl icon}} [http://nos.nl/artikel/2037740-vvd-wil-kiesdrempel-tegen-te-kleine-partijen.html VVD wil kiesdrempel tegen te kleine partijen], NOS, 26 May 2015 He also declared that he would make [[integrity]] a central theme. In April 2017 the Dutch platform for investigative journalism Follow the Money (FTM) published an article that accused Henry Keizer and three partners claiming that they had unfairly enriched themselves by buying an enterprise at a price that was below the actual value. It was also claimed that there was a conflict of interest, as Keizer was also an advisor to the sellers. Keizer denied the allegations and stated that they had done nothing wrong and claimed that the take-over was based on independent audit reports.{{cite web|title=VVD-praeses Henry Keizer ontkent zelfverrijking met uitvaartorganisatie|url=https://www.volkskrant.nl/politiek/vvd-praeses-henry-keizer-ontkent-zelfverrijking-met-uitvaartorganisatie-100-procent-schoon-geweten~a4490083/|publisher=de Volkskrant|accessdate=24 April 2017}} The former owners of the company officially supported this statement. His party for the time being decided not to consult its Integrity Committee.[http://www.elsevier.nl/nederland/achtergrond/2017/04/vvd-reageert-koeltjes-op-schandaal-rond-voorzitter-keizer-497442/ VVD reageert koeltjes op schandaal rond voorzitter Keizer, [[Elsevier]], 22 April 2017]. Later on at the request of Keizer the Integrity Committee of the VVD did start an investigation.[http://www.rd.nl/vandaag/politiek/integriteitsonderzoek-naar-vvd-voorzitter-1.1397233 Integriteitsonderzoek naar VVD-voorzitter], RD, 29 April 2017 Pending the results he decided to temporarily suspend his duties as president of the VVD.{{cite web|url=https://www.rtlz.nl/algemeen/politiek/henry-keizer-legt-vvd-voorzitterschap-voorlopig-neer-om-omstreden-deal|title=Henry Keizer legt VVD-voorzitterschap voorlopig neer om omstreden deal|website=rtlz.nl}} On 15 May 2017 Pieter Lakeman of the Dutch Foundation for Research Business Information (SOBI) filed a complaint against Keizer and his partners at the prosecutor's office.[http://politiek.eenvandaag.nl/tv-items/74107/aangifte_van_oplichting_tegen_vvd_er_henry_keizer Een Vandaag, aangifte van oplichting tegen VVD-er Henry Keizer], May 16, 2017. SOBI at the same time also filed a disciplinary complaint against the external auditor of the company at the Disciplinary Court for Accountants (Dutch Accountantskamer).{{cite web|url=https://www.accountant.nl/contentassets/8400a05e3b3844f884c34c72a5a550bc/tuchtklachtey10mei2017.pdf|website=Accountant.nl|publisher=Accountant|accessdate=10 May 2017|title=Tuchtklacht tegen drs. M de Kimpe RA}} On 18 May 2017 Keizer stepped down as Party Chairman.{{cite web|title=Verklaring Henry Keizer, partijvoorzitter VVD|url=https://www.vvd.nl/nieuws/verklaring-henry-keizer-partijvoorzitter-vvd/|website=VVD|publisher=VVD|accessdate=2 May 2017}} At the Party Congress later that year Christianne van der Wal was elected as his successor.{{cite web|title=Christianne van der Wal is de nieuwe partijvoorzitter|url=https://www.vvd.nl/nieuws/christianne-van-der-wal-is-de-nieuwe-partijvoorzitter/|website=VVD|accessdate=25 November 2017}} On 29 January 2018, the Dutch ‘Accountantskamer’ ruled and rejected all complaints and accusations against the accountant made by SOBI.{{cite web|title=Rechter spreekt accountant voormalig VVD-partijvoorzitter Keizer vrij|url=https://www.ad.nl/politiek/rechter-spreekt-accountant-voormalig-vvd-partijvoorzitter-keizer-vrij~ae1c50ca/|website=AD.nl|publisher=AD|accessdate=29 January 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{nl icon}} [http://www.henrykeizer.com/ Official website] {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Benk Korthals]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy#Leadership|Chairman of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]]|years=2014–2017}} {{end}} {{People's Party for Freedom and Democracy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Keizer, Henry}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Chairmen of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] [[Category:Chairmen of Trade associations of the Netherlands]] [[Category:Dutch businesspeople]] [[Category:Dutch corporate directors]] [[Category:Dutch expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:Funeral directors]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Amsterdam]] [[Category:People from The Hague]] [[Category:People's Party for Freedom and Democracy politicians]] {{Netherlands-VVD-politician-stub}}

{{orphan|date=September 2010}}
'''Import Genius''' is a provider of [[business intelligence]] for the import-export industry.
{{Infobox company | name = Import Genius | type = Private | industry = {{unbulleted list |Trade Data Services|Computer Software| Internet}} | foundation = United States (July 20, 2007) | founder = Ryan Petersen, David Petersen, Michael Kanko | location_city = Scottsdale, AZ, Shanghai, China, Manila, Philippines | location_country = United States | key_people = Michael Kanko, CEO; Nickie Bonenfant, COO; Paulo Marinas, CTO | homepage = {{URL|http://www.importgenius.com}} }}
== Intro == Import Genius gives customers access to shipping manifests for all shipments entering the United States of America in addition to several other countries around the world. In 2008, the company gained considerable notoriety by using [[U.S. Customs]] records to detect the arrival of the [[3G iPhone]] prior to [[Apple Computers|Apple's]] announcement of the phone.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|url=http://freakonomics.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/06/27/amazing-new-trade-data/ |title=Amazing New Trade Data |work=[[The New York Times]]|date=27 June 2008 | first=Justin | last=Wolfers}}</ref>
== Founders ==
* David Petersen, Founder * Michael Kanko, Founder and CEO * Ryan Petersen, Founder
== Business ==
Import Genius was founded by Ryan Petersen, David Petersen, and Michael Kanko. Import Genius was initially founded on July 20, 2007 however didn't become well known until a few years later. Import Genius was envisioned to be used as a database tool in order to assist importers and exporters involved with international trade. Import Genius' debut happened in 2008 when Ryan Petersen used the information found in Import Genius’s database to predict the release of the 3G iPhone.<ref name=WP>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/28/AR2008052802290.html |title=ImportGenius: The Disruptive Shipping Database |work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=28 May 2008 | first=Jason | last=Kincaid}}</ref><ref name=Wired>{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2009/02/wired-o-nomics/ |title=Transparency as a Stimulus |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=18 February 2009 | first= Evan | last=Ratcliff}}</ref> Since then, Import Genius has been developed not only for importers and exporters, but also to assist freight forwarders, investors,<ref name=SeekingAlpha>{{cite news|url=http://seekingalpha.com/article/1361781-kandi-technologies-customs-records-contradict-u-s-electric-vehicle-sales-claims |title=Kandi Technologies: Customs Records Contradict U.S. Electric-Vehicle Sales Claims |work=Seeking Alpha|date=23 April 2013}}</ref> researchers,<ref name=foodsafetynews>{{cite news|url=http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/08/honey-laundering/#.UcDEBPl4ydA |title=Asian Honey, Banned in Europe, Is Flooding U.S. Grocery Shelves |work=[[Food Safety News]]|date=15 August 2011 | first=Andrew | last=Schneider}}</ref> and even for legal purposes.

{{about|Incident management theory||Incident Management (ITSM)}} {{multiple issues|{{Globalize|date=August 2007}} {{refimprove|date=January 2018}}}}
{{Business administration}}An incident is an event that could lead to loss of, or disruption to, an organization's operations, services or functions. '''Incident management''' ('''IcM''') is a term describing the activities of an organization to identify, analyze, and correct hazards to prevent a future re-occurrence. These incidents within a structured organization are normally dealt with by either an [[incident response team]] (IRT), an [[incident management team]] (IMT), or [[Incident Command System]] (ICS). Without effective incident management, an incident can disrupt business operations, information security, IT systems, employees, customers, or other vital business functions.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/bdotg/action/detail?itemId=1084688800&r.l1=1073861197&r.l2=1075408323&r.l3=1084688133&r.s=sc&type=RESOURCES|title=What qualifies as an 'incident'? {{!}} Business Link|last=UK|first=Small Business Service, Kingsgate House, 66-74 Victoria Street, London SW1E 6SW,|website=webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-01-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110615004920/http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/bdotg/action/detail?itemId=1084688800&r.l1=1073861197&r.l2=1075408323&r.l3=1084688133&r.s=sc&type=RESOURCES|archivedate=2011-06-15|df=}}</ref>
== Description == An incident is an event that could lead to loss of, or disruption to, an organization's operations, services or functions.<ref>[http://www.thebci.org/glossary.pdf Glossary of Terms, The Business Continuity Institute Good Practice Guidelines 2010 Global Edition]. thebci.org Retrieved on 2015-09-03.</ref> Incident management (IcM) is a term describing the activities of an organization to identify, analyze, and correct hazards to prevent a future re-occurrence. If not managed, an incident can escalate into an emergency, crisis or a disaster. Incident management is therefore the process of limiting the potential disruption caused by such an event, followed by a return to business as usual. Without effective incident management, an incident can disrupt business operations, information security, IT systems, employees, customers, or other vital business functions.<ref name=":0" />
=== Physical incident management ===
Incident management is considered to be much more than just the analysis of perceived threats and hazards towards and organization in order to work out the risk of that event occurring, and therefore the ability of that organization to conduct business as usual activities during the incident. An important part of risk management process and business resilience planning that Incident management is a real time physical activity.
The planning that has happened to formulate the response to an incident—be that a disaster, emergency, crisis or accident—has been done so that effective business resilience can take place to ensure minimal loss or damage whether that is to tangible or non tangible assets of that organization. Efficient physical management of the incident—making best use of both time and resources that are available and understanding how to get more resources from outside the organization when needed by clear and timely liaison—ensure the plan is implemented.
[[National Fire Protection Association]] states that incident management can be described as, '[a]n IMS [incident management system] is "the combination of facilities, equipment, personnel, procedures and communications operating within a common organizational structure, designed to aid in the management of resources during incidents".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nfpa.org/aboutthecodes/AboutTheCodes.asp?DocNum=1600&cookie_test=1|title=List of NFPA Codes and Standards|date=2013|website=www.nfpa.org|language=en|access-date=10 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ready.gov/business/implementation/incident|title=Incident Management {{!}} Ready.gov|date=2012|website=www.ready.gov|access-date=10 April 2013}}</ref>
The physical incident management is the real time response that may last for hours, days, or longer. The [[Cabinet Office|United Kingdom Cabinet Office]] have produced the National Recovery Guidance (NRG), which is aimed at [[First responder|local responders]] as part of the implementation of the [[Civil Contingencies Act 2004]] (CCA). It describes the response as the following: "Response encompasses the actions taken to deal with the immediate effects of an emergency. In many scenarios, it is likely to be relatively short and to last for a matter of hours or days – rapid implementation of arrangements for collaboration, co-ordination and communication are, therefore, vital. Response encompasses the effort to deal not only with the direct effects of the emergency itself (eg fighting fires, rescuing individuals) but also the indirect effects (eg disruption, media interest)".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/national-recovery-guidance|title=National Recovery Guidance - GOV.UK|year=2007|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=10 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2004/36/contents|title=Civil Contingencies Act 2004|year=2012|website=www.legislation.gov.uk|language=en|others=Expert Participation|access-date=10 April 2013}}</ref>
[[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which is the world's largest developer of international standards also makes a point in the description of its risk management, principles and guidelines document [[ISO 31000]]:2009 that, "Using ISO 31000 can help organizations increase the likelihood of achieving objectives, improve the identification of opportunities and threats and effectively allocate and use resources for risk treatment".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iso.org/iso/home/standards/iso31000.htm|title=ISO 31000 Risk management|year=2009|website=www.iso.org|language=en|access-date=13 April 2013}}</ref> This again shows the importance of not just good planning but effective allocation of resources to treat the risk.
=== Computer security incident management === {{Main|Computer security incident management}} Today, an important role is played by a Computer Security Incident Response Team (CSIRT), due to the rise of internet crime, and is a common example of incident faced by companies in developed nations all across the world. For example, if an organization discovers that an intruder has gained unauthorized access to a computer system, the CSIRT would analyze the situation, determine the breadth of the compromise, and take corrective action. [[Computer forensics]] is one task included in this process. Currently, over half of the world’s hacking attempts on Trans National Corporations (TNCs) take place in North America (57%). 23% of attempts take place in Europe.<ref>[http://blogs.technet.com/b/rhalbheer/archive/2010/03/12/hacking-incidents-2009-interesting-data.aspx Hacking Incidents 2009 – Interesting Data – Roger's Security Blog – Site Home – TechNet Blogs]. Blogs.technet.com (2010-03-12). Retrieved on 2012-11-17.</ref> Having a well-rounded Computer Security Incident Response team is integral to providing a secure environment for any organization, and is becoming a critical part of the overall design of many modern networking teams.
== Roles == Incidents within a structured organization are normally dealt with by either an [[incident response team]] (IRT), or an [[incident management team]] (IMT). These are often designated beforehand or during the event, and are placed in control of the organization whilst the incident is dealt with, to restore normal functions.
The [[Incident Command System]] (ICS) is designed to deal with a larger incident involving a respond from multiple agencies. Popular with [[public safety]] agencies and jurisdictions in the United States, Canada and other countries, it is growing in practice in the private sector as organizations begin to manage without or co-manage emergencies with public safety agencies. ICS is a command and control mechanism that provides an expandable structure to manage emergency agencies. Although some of the details vary by jurisdiction, ICS normally consists of five primary elements: command, operations, planning, logistics and finance/administration. Several special staff positions, including public affairs, safety, and liaison, report directly to the incident commander (IC) when the emergency warrants establishment of those positions.
Another response system is the [[Gold–silver–bronze command structure]], which is used by emergency services in the United Kingdom and other countries. The system has three levels of command: a gold commander sets the overall strategy, a silver commander is in direct charge of those at the scene and bronze commanders direct responders on the ground. An individual agency may use the system, or multiple agencies may use the system as they liaise. A common feature of the ICS and Gold-Silver-Bronze systems is that they create a separate command system to the agencies' usual hierarchy.
Usually as part of the wider management process in private organizations, incident management is followed by post-incident analysis where it is determined why the incident happened despite precautions and controls. This analysis is normally overseen by the leaders of the organization, with the view of preventing repetition of the incident through precautionary measures and often changes in policy. This information is then used as feedback to further develop the security policy and/or its practical implementation. In the United States, the [[National Incident Management System]], developed by the [[Department of Homeland Security]], integrates effective practices in emergency management into a comprehensive national framework. This often results in a higher level of contingency planning, exercise and training, as well as an evaluation of the management of the incident.<ref>[https://www.dhs.gov/xabout/structure/gc_1230910518359.shtm About the Contingency Planning and Incident Management Division | Homeland Security] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402131642/https://www.dhs.gov/xabout/structure/gc_1230910518359.shtm |date=April 2, 2012 }}. Dhs.gov (1999-02-22). Retrieved on 2012-11-17.</ref>
== Incident management software systems == Incident management software systems are designed for collecting consistent, time sensitive, documented [[incident report]] data. Many of these products include features to automate the approval process of an incident report or case investigation. These products may also have the ability to collect real time incident information such as time and date data. Additionally incident report systems will automatically send notifications, assign tasks and escalations to appropriate individuals depending on the incident type, priority, time, status and custom criteria. Modern products provide the ability for administrators to configure the Incident report forms as needed, create analysis reports and set access controls on the data. These incident reports may have the ability for customization that may best suit the organizations using the systems. Some of these products have the ability to collect images, video, audio and other data. Incident management software systems exist that relate directly to specific industries.
== Root cause analysis == {{Main|root cause analysis}}
=== Human factors === {{One source|section | date = January 2018 }}
During the [[root cause analysis]], human factors should be assessed. James Reason conducted a study into the understanding of adverse effects of human factors.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Reason J | title = Understanding adverse events: human factors | journal = Quality in Health Care | volume = 4 | issue = 2 | pages = 80–9 | date = June 1995 | pmid = 10151618 | pmc = 1055294 }}</ref> The study found that major incident investigations, such as [[Piper Alpha]] and [[Kings Cross Underground fire|Kings Cross Underground Fire]], made it clear that the causes of the accidents were distributed widely within and outside the organization. There are two types of events: active failure—an action that has immediate effects and has the likelihood to cause an accident—and latent or delayed action—events can take years to have an effect and are usually combined with triggering events that then cause the accident.
Active failures are unsafe acts (errors and violations) committed by, for instance, the operators of machinery and supervisors of tasks. It is the people at the human-system interface whose actions can have immediate adverse consequences.
Latent failures are created as the result of decisions taken at the higher echelons of an organisation. Their damaging consequences may lie dormant for a long time, only becoming evident when they combine with local triggering factors (e.g., the [[spring tide]], the loading difficulties at [[Zeebrugge]] harbour, etc.) to breach the system's defences. Decisions taken in the higher echelons of an organization can trigger the events towards an accident becoming more likely, the planning, scheduling, forecasting, designing, policy making, etc., can have a slow burning effect. The actual unsafe act that triggers an accident can be traced back through the organization and the subsequent failures can be exposed, showing the accumulation of latent failures within the system as a whole that led to the accident becoming more likely and ultimately happening. Better improvement action can be applied, and reduce the likelihood of the event happening again.<ref>O’Callaghan, Katherine Mary, [http://dlibrary.acu.edu.au/digitaltheses/public/adt-acuvp272.01032011/index.html Incident Management: Human Factors and Minimising Mean Time to Restore] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110917053506/http://dlibrary.acu.edu.au/digitaltheses/public/adt-acuvp272.01032011/index.html |date=2011-09-17 }}, Ph.D. Thesis, Australian Catholic University, 2010.</ref>

{{about|data brokers|a degreed librarian who performs information research, also known as an independent information professional, information consultant, information specialist, Internet researcher, or Internet librarian|information professional}}
An '''information broker''' or '''data broker''' collects information about individuals from [[public records]] and private sources including [[census]] and [[change of address]] records, [[motor vehicle]] and [[driving]] records, [[User-generated content|user-contributed material]] to [[social networking sites]],<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.propublica.org/article/yes-companies-are-harvesting-and-selling-your-social-media-profiles|title = Yes, Companies Are Harvesting – and Selling – Your Facebook Profile|last = Beckette|first = Lois|date = 9 November 2012|work = |accessdate = 17 August 2014}}</ref> [[News story|media]] and court reports, [[voter registration]] lists, consumer purchase histories, [[Most wanted list|most-wanted]] lists and terrorist watch lists, [[payment card|bank card transaction records]], health care authorities, and [[Web browsing history|web browsing histories]].<ref name="worldprivacyforum.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldprivacyforum.org/2013/12/testimony-what-information-do-data-brokers-have-on-consumers/|title=Congressional Testimony: What Information Do Data Brokers Have on Consumers?|publisher=}}</ref>
The data are [[Aggregate data|aggregated]] to create individual profiles, often made up of thousands of individual pieces of information such as a person's age, race, gender, height, weight, marital status, religious affiliation, political affiliation, occupation, household income, net worth, home ownership status, investment habits, product preferences and health-related interests. Brokers then sell the profiles to other organizations that use them mainly to target advertising and marketing towards specific groups, to verify a person's identity including for purposes of fraud detection, and to sell to individuals and organizations so they can research people for various reasons.<ref name="Government of the United States">{{Cite web|url = http://www.ftc.gov/system/files/documents/reports/data-brokers-call-transparency-accountability-report-federal-trade-commission-may-2014/140527databrokerreport.pdf|title = DATA BROKERS: A Call for Transparency and Accountability|date = May 2014|accessdate = 13 August 2014|website = Federal Trade Commission|publisher = Government of the United States|last = |first = }}</ref> Data brokers also often sell the profiles to government agencies, such as the FBI, thus allowing law enforcement agencies to circumvent laws that protect privacy.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Etzioni|first1=Amitai|title=Reining in Private Agents|journal=Minnesota Law Review|date=2016|volume=101|pages=279–331|ssrn=2869439}}</ref>
== Overview == Beginning in the late twentieth century, technological developments such as the development of the [[internet]], increasing computer processing power and declining costs of [[Computer data storage|data storage]] made it much easier for companies to collect, analyze, store and transfer large amounts of data about individual people. This gave rise to the information broker or data broker industry.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|first1 = |last1 = |first2 = |last2 = |first3 = |last3 = |first4 = |last4 = |title = Big data: seizing opportunities, preserving values|url = http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/docs/big_data_privacy_report_may_1_2014.pdf|date = |publisher =Executive Office of the President |website = |accessdate = Aug 17, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610084800/https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/docs/big_data_privacy_report_may_1_2014.pdf|archivedate=2014-06-10}}</ref>
Individuals generally cannot find out what data a broker holds on them, how a broker got it, or how it is used.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.privacyrights.org/online-info-broker-faq |title=Online Information Broker FAQ |work= Privacy Rights Clearinghouse |publisher=privacyrights.org |date=October 4, 2010 |accessdate=May 6, 2014}}</ref> Some data brokers retain all information indefinitely.
Files on individuals are generally sold in lists; examples cited in testimony to the U.S. Congress include lists of rape victims, seniors with dementia, financially vulnerable people, people with HIV, and police officers (by home address).<ref name="worldprivacyforum.org"/><ref name="commerce.senate.gov"/> Less controversial are lists of rich people, doctors, or parents.
There are probably between 3500 and 4000 data broker companies, and about a third may provide opt-outs, with some charging over a thousand dollars for them.<ref name="worldprivacyforum.org"/>
Data brokers collect information concerning myriad topics, ranging from the daily communications of an individual to more specialized data such as product registrations.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Data Revolution|last=Kitchin|first=Rob|publisher=Sage Publications Ltd. (UK)|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
== Brokers and datasets == Data brokers in the United States include [[Acxiom]]{{dn|date=November 2018}}, [[Experian]], [[Alliance Data#Epsilon|Epsilon]], [[CoreLogic]], [[Datalogix]], [[inome]], [[PeekYou]], [[Exactis]], and [[Recorded Future]].<ref name="Government of the United States"/><ref name="commerce.senate.gov">http://educationnewyork.com/files/rockefeller_databroker.pdf</ref> Acxiom claims to have files on 10% of the world's population,<ref name="commerce.senate.gov"/> with about 1500 pieces of information per consumer<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/17/technology/acxiom-the-quiet-giant-of-consumer-database-marketing.html</ref> (quoted in [[Senate.gov]]).<ref name="commerce.senate.gov"/> In 2017, [[Cambridge Analytica]] claimed that it has psychological profiles of 220 million US citizens based on 5,000 separate data sets<ref name="InkJun2017">{{cite news |url=https://series.fountainink.in/aadhaar-in-the-hand-of-spies |title=Aadhaar in the hand of spies Big Data, global surveillance state and the identity project |author=Govind Krishnan V. |date=3 June 2017 |accessdate=27 August 2017 |publisher=Fountain Ink Magazine |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826163725/https://series.fountainink.in/aadhaar-in-the-hand-of-spies/ |archivedate=26 August 2017 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> (another 2017 claim is 230 million Americans<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/17/data-war-whistleblower-christopher-wylie-faceook-nix-bannon-trump</ref>).
==History== Credit scores were first used in the 1950s, but did not become widely known or specifically regulated until the 1990s.<ref name="worldprivacyforum.org"/>
In 1977 [[Kelly Warnken]] published the first fee-based information directory, which continues to be published and has expanded to cover international concerns.
==Criticism== A U.S. Senate Committee in 2013 published ''A Review of the Data Broker Industry: Collection, Use, and Sale of Consumer Data for Marketing Purposes''.<ref name="commerce.senate.gov"/> It states that "Today, a wide range of companies known as “data brokers” collect and maintain data on hundreds of millions of consumers, which they analyze, package, and sell generally without consumer permission or input." Their main findings were that: *Data brokers collect a huge volume of detailed information on hundreds of millions of consumers. *Data brokers sell products that identify financially vulnerable consumers. *Data broker products provide information about consumer offline behavior to tailor online outreach by marketers. *Data brokers operate behind a veil of secrecy.
The information produced by data brokers has been criticized for enabling discrimination in pricing, services and opportunities. For example, a May 2014 White House report found that web searches that included black-seeming first names such as Jermaine were more likely to result in ads being displayed that include the word "arrest," compared with web searches including white-seeming first names such as Geoffrey.<ref name=":0" />
An Online Information Broker FAQ<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.privacyrights.org/online-info-broker-faq|title=Online Information Broker FAQ|publisher=}}</ref> is published by [[Privacy Rights Clearinghouse]] (PRC), a nonprofit consumer organization in the United States. PRC also maintains a list of information brokers (data brokers, with links to their privacy policies, terms of service, and opt-out privisions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.privacyrights.org/online-information-brokers-list|title=- Privacy Rights Clearinghouse|publisher=}}</ref>
Data brokers have also faced legal charges for security breaches due to poor data security practices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2008/03/agency-announces-settlement-separate-actions-against-retailer-tjx|title=Agency Announces Settlement of Separate Actions Against Retailer TJX, and Data Brokers Reed Elsevier and Seisint for Failing to Provide Adequate Security for Consumers Data|publisher=}}</ref>
== Calls for regulation and legislation == A 2007 [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]] study, after requesting and analyzing information-sharing practices at 86 companies, found many operating under an [[opt-out]] model that it described as inconsistent with consumer expectations, and recommended that the [[California State Legislature|California state legislature]] require companies to disclose their information-sharing policies using clear, unambiguous language, and consider creating a centralized, user-friendly method for consumers to opt out of information-sharing.<ref>{{Cite journal|ssrn = 1137990|title = Consumer Information Sharing: Where the Sun Still Don't Shine|last = Hoofnagle, and Jennifer King|first = Chris Jay|date = 17 December 2007|journal = (working paper)|accessdate = |doi = |pmid = |archiveurl = }}</ref>
In 2009, the [[Federal Trade Commission|U.S. Federal Trade Commission]] had recommended the U.S. Congress develop legislation enabling consumers to see the information that data brokers hold about them, a recommendation it renewed in subsequent reports in 2012 and 2014. In 2013, the U.S. Government Accountability Office also called for Congress to consider legislation.<ref name="Government of the United States"/><ref name="FTC">{{cite web|title=TC Recommends Congress Require the Data Broker Industry to be More Transparent and Give Consumers Greater Control Over Their Personal Information|url=http://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2014/05/ftc-recommends-congress-require-data-broker-industry-be-more|publisher=Federal Trade Commission|accessdate=31 May 2014}}</ref>
==Regulation attempts== The [[Data Accountability and Trust Act]] contained a number of requirements for auditing and verification of accuracy of data held by information brokers, and additional measures in the case of a security breach. The bill also gave identified individuals the means and opportunity to review and correct the data held that related to them. It passed through the [[United States House of Representatives]] in the [[111th Congress]], but failed to pass the [[United States Senate]]. It was revived by the [[112th Congress]] in 2011 as H.R. 1707.,<ref>[http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr1707 Data Accountability and Trust Act (2011; 112th Congress H.R. 1707)]. GovTrack.us. Retrieved on 2013-11-12.</ref> but died after being referred to committee. The bill was first introduced by Rep. [[Bobby Rush]] [D-IL1] on Apr 30, 2009, H.R. 2221<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/111/hr2221 |title=Data Accountability and Trust Act (2009; 111th Congress H.R. 2221) |publisher= govtrack.us |accessdate=November 12, 2013}}</ref>
==Fiction== In [[fiction]], information brokers usually find data for a story's main character(s). Fictional information brokers can be of varying importance and have varying methods. For example, a [[Hacker (computer security)|hacker]] can be an information broker, though they may be simply transferring whatever information they find to the main character(s). Other brokers may have [[memorize]]d data and tell the main character(s) [[covert]]ly. Also, a fee is not always involved. The information broker may have an alliance with the main character(s) or be one themselves.
Examples of information brokers in contemporary fiction would be [[Edward G. Robinson]]'s character Sol in the film ''[[Soylent Green]]''; the Shadow Broker in the video game series ''[[Mass Effect]]''; Nicholas Wayne, Rachel, Elean Duga, Gustav St. Germain, Carol, and the President of the Daily Days newspaper company in ''[[Baccano!]]''; or Izaya Orihara in the light novel series ''[[Durarara!!]]''. A few of the characters in [[Neil Stephenson]]'s novel [[Snow Crash]] find work selling data as "stringers" for the Central Intelligence Corporation. Information broker characters play a prominent role in stories published by [[DC Comics]]. The character trope is best exemplified by the superhero [[Barbara Gordon|Oracle]], but the trope is later used with the characters [[Calculator (comics)|Calculator]], [[Wendy and Marvin|Proxy]], [[Chloe Sullivan]], and [[Felicity Smoak]] as well.

{{Infobox person | name = Jean-Claude Biver | image = Jean-Claude Biver - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2012.jpg | alt = | caption = Biver at the [[World Economic Forum]] annual meeting in 2012 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1949|09|20}} | birth_place = [[Luxembourg]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | known_for = Businesses exploits in the [[Swiss made|Swiss watchmaking industry]] | alma_mater = Collège de Morges
[[University of Lausanne]] | occupation = {{hlist|Watchmaker|cheesemaker|businessman}} }} '''Jean-Claude Biver''' (born September 20, 1949) is a Luxembourgish [[watchmaker]], [[Cheesemaking|cheesemaker]], and businessman currently serving as the [[chief executive officer]] (CEO) of [[TAG Heuer]]. In January 2014, he was named the president of [[Louis Vuitton]]'s watchmaking division. Since 2014, he served as chief executive, board member, and minority [[shareholder]] of [[Hublot]], a [[Swiss]] luxury [[watchmaker]].{{Cite web |title=The History of Hublot Geneve |url=http://www.hublot.com/wwwdata/historique/HISTORY_HUBLOT.EN.pdf |publisher=Hublot |accessdate=2009-11-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712230339/http://www.hublot.com/wwwdata/historique/HISTORY_HUBLOT.EN.pdf# |archive-date=2011-07-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Biver has been successful at Hublot, and was previously successful in rejuvenating the [[Blancpain]] and [[Omega SA|Omega]] brands, both currently owned by [[The Swatch Group|Swatch Group]]. Biver is also known for his own exclusive [[cheese]]. Biver's leadership in the Swiss watch industry has been credited as "single handedly {{sic}} ... saving [the industry] from the [[Quartz clock|quartz]] movement."{{Cite web |last=Margolis |first=Mike |title=A TimeZone Interview with Jean-Claude Biver |url=http://www.timezone.com/library/tzints/200508081757 |publisher=Timezone.com |date=May 2005 |accessdate=2009-11-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090724163557/http://www.timezone.com/library/tzints/200508081757# |archive-date=2009-07-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In 1980, even prestigious Swiss watch brands had "a proportion of 70% more or less quartz [[Movement (clockwork)|movement]]s in their collection;" since then, the Swiss watch industry has staged a "remarkable recovery", with 2008 exports valued at [[Swiss franc|CHF]]17 billion.{{Cite web |title=Salesman of the irrational |url=http://www.economist.com/people/displaystory.cfm?story_id=14857221 |publisher=''[[The Economist]]'' |date=2009-11-12 |accessdate=2009-11-30}} ==Early life and career== Biver was born on September 20, 1949, in [[Luxembourg]], and at the age of 10 moved with his family to [[Switzerland]], attending school in [[Saint Prex]]. He later studied at Collège des Morges, and earned a degree in [[business]] at [[HEC Lausanne]] (also known as the Faculty of Business and Economics of the [[University of Lausanne]]). Upon graduation, he spent time in the [[Vallée de Joux]], absorbing the culture of [[watchmaking]], where he met [[Jacques Piguet]], who was running the [[Movement (clockwork)|movement]] factory [[Frederic Piguet]]. Through Jacques' father, he met Georges Golay, chairman and CEO of [[Audemars Piguet]], where he was offered a job as sales manager for Europe. In a year of working for AP, he was able to learn the "art of watchmaking," though he left after a year, thinking he could do better elsewhere. He left Audemars Piguet to become product manager at [[Omega SA|Omega]], a major multinational brand, leaving Omega after a year to return to the ''[[manufacture d'horlogerie]]'' of the Vallée de Joux. Jean-Claude Biver was awarded a [[Honorary degree|Doctor Honoris Causa]] from [[Business School Lausanne]] in 2012 in recognition of his contribution to the success of the Swiss watchmaking industry.{{cite journal |title=Jean Claude Biver|url=https://www.bsl-lausanne.ch/people/jean-claude-biver/|journal=BSL Lausanne|date = 2017}} ==Watch industry== ===Blancpain=== Upon return to the Valley de Joux in 1981, Biver and Jacques Piguet purchased the rights to [[Blancpain]], a watchmaker that had gone out of business in the 1970s. Blancpain had a long history but had been rendered obsolete by the development of [[quartz watch]]es. Using this as a strength, Biver and Piguet rebuilt the brand on the concept that "Since 1735 there has never been a quartz Blancpain watch. And there never will be." Blancpain quickly became one of the most respected traditional watch brands, achieving a turnover of [[Swiss franc|CHF]]50m. In 1992, the brand was sold to [[Société de Microélectronique et d'Horlogerie|SMH Group]] (now known as [[The Swatch Group|Swatch Group]]) for CHF60m ([[USD]]43m), having been initially purchased for CHF22,000. Biver remained CEO of Blancpain until 2003. ===Omega=== Upon the sale of Blancpain, Biver joined the board of directors of Swatch Group, where he was charged with turning around Swatch's [[Omega SA|Omega]] brand. Biver's main influence was in the product and marketing fields, employing techniques such as [[product placement]] (notably in [[James Bond]] films) and celebrity sponsorships (including testimonials from [[Cindy Crawford]], [[Michael Schumacher]], and [[Pierce Brosnan]]). Biver left Omega in 2003, having presided over the company's "dazzling" recovery. Over Biver's ten years at Omega, its sales had almost tripled. ===Hublot=== Biver briefly exited the watchmaking world in 2004, before joining [[Hublot]] as CEO and board member. At Hublot, he has emphasized "the fusion of tradition and future." Hublot was bought by [[LVMH]] in 2008, following a fivefold increase in sales from 2004 to 2007. Even in the [[late-2000s recession]], Hublot has been considered to be very successful, with sales down 15% up to November 2009 compared with 30% for the entire Swiss luxury watch business. Biver has retained the brand's exclusivity through methods such as restricting supply in the face of large demand, citing that "people want exclusivity, so you must always keep the customer hungry and frustrated." ===TAG Heuer=== Biver became the CEO of [[TAG Heuer]] in December 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaljeweler.com/watches/brand-profiles/TAG-Heuer-CEO-resigns-as-brand-lowers-its-sights-6497.shtml|title=TAG Heuer CEO Resigns|publisher=nationaljeweler.com|date=December 12, 2014|access-date=2015-04-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150406055418/http://www.nationaljeweler.com/watches/brand-profiles/TAG-Heuer-CEO-resigns-as-brand-lowers-its-sights-6497.shtml#|archive-date=2015-04-06|dead-url=yes|df=}} The company's thirty-year cooperation with the [[McLaren]] motorsport team came to an end in late 2015, after Biver had a falling out with McLaren owner [[Ron Dennis]]. TAG Heuer subsequently joined [[Red Bull Racing]], becoming namesake to their [[Renault in Formula One|Renault]] engines.{{cite web|last1=Parkes|first1=Ian|title=McLaren's Ron Dennis admits he fell out with TAG Heuer chief|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/122135|website=autosport.com|accessdate=5 December 2015|date=4 December 2015}}{{cite web|title=Timing is Everything|url=http://www.infiniti-redbullracing.com/article/timing-everything|publisher=Red Bull Racing|accessdate=5 December 2015|date=4 December 2015}} ==Cheese== Every year, Biver produces approximately five [[tonne]]s of cheese at his farm in the [[Swiss Alps]]. Biver produces cheese for only a few weeks every summer during which the alpine meadows [[flower]], rendering "a flowery taste to the milk and subsequently, to the cheese."{{Cite web |last=Bhattacharya |first=Mitrajit |title=Cheese & Crackers: Get a taste of Hublot President Jean-Claude Biver's passion for cheese |url=http://www.watchworldmagazine.com/watchworld/vol9/anecdote.asp |publisher=''Watch World'' Magazine |accessdate=2009-11-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090807090955/http://www.watchworldmagazine.com/watchworld/vol9/anecdote.asp# |archive-date=2009-08-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Because of the cheese's exclusivity, Biver refuses payment, offering cheese only to his friends and family, and to particular restaurants of his choosing. Biver stated that by refusing payment, he can remain in absolute control of the cheese's distribution: "I will be the master of my cheese until the last piece." ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *{{de icon}} [http://www.top-magazin-frankfurt.de/redaktion/business-finance/hublot-jean-claude-biver-die-fortsetzung-der-kindheit/ Hublot – Die Fortsetzung der Kindheit] Portrait about Jean-Claude Biver {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Biver, Jean-Claude}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Swiss businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Lausanne alumni]] [[Category:Swiss chief executives]] [[Category:Swiss corporate directors]]

{{Infobox Journal | abbreviation = | cover = Journal of Knowledge Management Cover.png | caption =A cover of ''Journal of Knowledge Management (JKM)'' | discipline = [[Knowledge management]] | website = http://emeraldgrouppublishing.com/products/journals/journals.htm?id=jkm | publisher = Emerald Insight | country = [[United Kingdom]] | frequency = Quarterly | history = 1997-present | ISSN = 1367-3270 }} The '''''Journal of Knowledge Management''''' ('''JKM''') is an [[interdisciplinarity|interdisciplinary]] [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] quarterly [[academic journal]] publishing original research, technical discussions, and case studies on [[knowledge management]]. According to its homepage, it is indexed in [[Library and Information Science Abstracts]], [[Inspec]], and [[Scopus]]. It has also been accepted in Thomson Reuters [[Social Sciences Citation Index]] and its current impact factor is 2.053, according to 2016 Journal Citation Reports® (Thomson Reuters, 2017). JKM is regarded as the premier journal in the field of knowledge management.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/products/journals/journals.htm?id=jkm |title=Journal of Knowledge Management |publisher=Emerald Insight |accessdate=16 December 2012}}</ref>

'''Jørgen Mads Clausen''' (born 23 September 1948) is the chairman of the board of [[Danfoss]], the large [[Denmark|Danish]] [[heating]], [[refrigeration]] and [[air conditioning]] company started by his father, [[Mads Clausen]]. He is also the chairman of DI, the association of the Danish Industry, and has a sizeable investment in the [[WaveStar]] wave energy project.

{{multiple issues| {{original research|date=December 2015}} {{More citations needed|date=February 2010}} }} {{Infobox Radio station | name = KYCR | image = File:KYCR am1440 logo.jpg | city = [[Golden Valley, Minnesota]] | area = [[Minneapolis-St. Paul]] | branding = ''Twin Cities Business Radio'' | slogan = | airdate = May 1948 (as KEYD) | frequency = 1440 [[kHz]] | format = [[Business journalism|Business]] [[Talk radio|Talk]] | power = 5,000 [[watt]]s (day)
500 watts (night) | class = B | facility_id = 35504 | coordinates = {{Coord|44|59|20|N|93|21|6|W|region:US-MN_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | callsign_meaning = Former callsign of sister station [[KDIZ (AM)|KDIZ]] ('''K''' '''Y'''our '''C'''hristian '''R'''adio) | former_callsigns = KEYD (1948-1956)
KEVE (1956-1964)
KQRS (1964-1982)
KGLD (1982-1984)
KQRS (1984-1996)
KDIZ (1996-2015) | affiliations = Wall Street Business Network | owner = [[Salem Media Group]] | licensee = Salem Communications Holding Corporation | sister_stations = [[KDIZ (AM)|KDIZ]], [[KKMS (AM)|KKMS]], [[WWTC]] | webcast = [http://saleminteractivemedia.com/ListenLive/Player/KYCRAM Listen Live] | website = [http://www.twincitiesbusinessradio.com twincitiesbusinessradio.com] }} '''KYCR''' (1440 [[AM broadcasting|AM]]) is a [[radio station]] serving the [[Minneapolis-St. Paul]] metropolitan area. It is owned by [[Salem Media Group]], and is carrying a business radio format. KYCR's studios are located in [[Eagan, Minnesota|Eagan]], while its transmitter is located in Golden Valley. ==History== [[File:Radio Disney1440 2010.png|left|150px|thumb|''Radio Disney 1440'' logo used from 2010 to 2013.]] The original call letters were '''KEYD''' and the station played [[country music]] for many years. The station was launched in May 1948 by former management and advertisers of [[KFAN (AM)|WDGY]], who had become disenchanted with the owners of that station over the discontinuance of religious programming. Family Broadcasting basically started the station as a new home for the spurned WDGY programming. KEYD got a sister TV station in 1955, KEYD-TV 9 (now [[KMSP-TV]]), and the two stations were co-owned by Family Broadcasting until mid-[[1956 in radio|1956]]. The original KEYD radio studios were located in downtown [[Minneapolis]] on 9th Street off of Hennepin Avenue practically next to the Orpheum Theater (see photo link below). According to the 1955 Broadcasting Yearbook, both the AM and TV stations were co-located in the Foshay Tower by the end of 1955. The [[call sign]] was changed to '''KEVE''' in June 1956{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gAoEAAAAMBAJ|title=Billboard|last=Inc|first=Nielsen Business Media|date=1956-06-23|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|language=en}} and the studios moved to the station's transmitter and antenna site at 917 Lilac Drive in Golden Valley. During that time, the station played [[country music]]. [[KQRS-FM|KEVE-FM]] (92.5 FM) signed on September 1, 1962, and by October 1963, it was given the call letters '''KADM''' to match its AM sister as the pair became known as "Adam and Eve in the Valley"; the city of license for the two stations is the suburb of Golden Valley. A gradual shift from country music to a mix of [[classical music]], [[show tunes]] and [[adult standards]] began in 1960 and was completed on both stations by March 1963.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fQsEAAAAMBAJ|title=Billboard|last=Inc|first=Nielsen Business Media|date=1963-03-30|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|language=en}} On December 1, 1964, the call letters for both stations became '''[[KQRS-FM|KQRS]]''' for "Quality Radio Stations". In 1967, the stations began experimenting with [[freeform (radio format)|freeform rock]] music from midnight to 5 AM every night via the "Night Watch" program, playing [[rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[jazz]] and [[psychedelic rock]]. The foray proved successful and by the end of 1968 it became the full-time format. The two KQs were a simulcast until 1982, when the AM briefly switched to an [[oldies]] format as '''KGLD''' before returning to the simulcast. The KGLD calls became effective November 22, 1982, with the KQRS calls returning on March 28, 1984. In 1985, [[ABC Radio Network]], then a division of the original [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC, Inc.]] bought the station and its main FM counterpart with it from previous owner Hudson Communications Corporation, a radio broadcasting company owned by [[Washington D.C.]] lawyer Joe McKenna, which owned the station from 1956 to 1985. Along with its main FM sister, it was ABC's first foray into the Minnesota broadcast market. At first, ABC programmed the station with a [[classic rock]] format, albeit essentially being an AM simulcast of its FM sister at the time from 1985 until 1996. The station again broke away from the simulcast in late 1996, this time permanently, when it became one of the four initial affiliates of the new Radio Disney with a children's format that competed with [[WWTC]], then the flagship station of "[[Radio Aahs]]," which had its own children's format. The station's call letters changed to '''KDIZ''' on November 15, 1996. With the advent of [[HD Radio]], KDIZ began broadcasting with the technology, as did most other Radio Disney affiliates. Disney had previously been collaborating with [[Children's Broadcasting Corporation|Radio Aahs]], which was based in Minneapolis and had launched its children's format in 1990. Radio Aahs had grown to approximately 30 affiliate stations around the country. Disney withdrew from the Aahs contract and began competing against Aahs with Radio Disney. Children's Broadcasting Corp. sued Disney and was awarded $9.5 million in 2002. Disney appealed, and after the court upheld the judgement, it was paid in 2005; with accumulated interest, the total was $12.4 million. On November 12, 2005, the station made world news when a riot erupted at its "Jingle Jam Concert" featuring [[B5 (band)|B5]], forcing the venue, Brookdale Mall, to be closed. Members of the group were stripped of shirts, shoes and earrings. On August 13, 2014, Disney put KDIZ and twenty-two other [[Radio Disney]] stations up for sale, in order to focus more on digital distribution of the Radio Disney network.{{cite news|last1=Lafayette|first1=Jon|title=Exclusive: Radio Disney Moving Off Air to Digital|url=http://broadcastingcable.com/news/currency/exclusive-radio-disney-moving-air-digital/133166|accessdate=August 13, 2014|date=August 13, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Radio Disney to Sell the Majority of Its Stations|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/6214509/radio-disney-to-sell-the-majority-of-its-stations|website=Billboard|accessdate=13 August 2014|ref=13 August 2014}} It held the distinction of being not only the longest-tenured Radio Disney station in its history, but also one of ABC's longest-tenured non-mainstream radio stations in its history. It was also the last-remaining Disney/ABC broadcast property in Minnesota, having had sold the others in 2007, with ABC Radio going to [[Citadel Broadcasting]] ([[KXXR]], acquired in 1993, [[Love 105]], acquired in 1997, and [[KQRS-FM]], acquired in 1985). On September 15, 2015, it was announced that [[Salem Media Group]] acquired the last five Radio Disney owned-and-operated stations for sale (including KDIZ) for $2.225 million.{{Cite web|url=https://radioinsight.com/blog/headlines/94556/salem-acquires-radio-disneys-final-five/|title=Salem Acquires Radio Disney’s Final Five|date=2015-09-15|website=RadioInsight|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-08}} KDIZ was acquired through Common Ground Broadcasting, Inc., for $375.000.{{cite web|title=Application for Consent to Assignment of Broadcast Station Construction Permit or License|url=http://licensing.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/ws.exe/prod/cdbs/forms/prod/prefill_and_display.pl?Application_id=1686442&Service=AM&Form_id=314&Facility_id=35504|work=CDBS Public Access|publisher=[[Federal Communications Commission]]}} Salem put a business format on the station in December 2015 (taken from 1570 AM),{{Cite web|url=https://radioinsight.com/blog/headlines/95554/salem-debuts-new-stations-in-denver-minneapolis/|title=Salem Debuts New Stations In Denver & Minneapolis|date=2015-12-17|website=RadioInsight|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-08}} after a brief period of silence. The format features [[Dave Ramsey]] and other business-talk oriented shows.{{cite web|title=St. Cloud AM DX logs|url=http://www.ubstudios.com/stcloudam.html|work=Ubstudios.com|accessdate=December 12, 2015}} The sale of KDIZ was completed on December 15, 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://licensing.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/ws.exe/prod/cdbs/forms/prod/prefill_and_display.pl?Application_id=1712715&Service=AM&Form_id=905&Facility_id=35504|title=Application View ... Redirecting|last=Staff|first=FCC Internet Services|website=licensing.fcc.gov|access-date=2016-05-08}} The station changed its callsign to KYCR on December 24th.[https://licensing.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/ws.exe/prod/cdbs/pubacc/prod/call_hist.pl?Facility_id=35504&Callsign=KYCR Call Sign History - Federal Communications Commission] With the sale to Salem, the company shut off the station's HD Radio transmission. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{AM station data|KYCR}} *[http://collections.mnhs.org/visualresources/image.cfm?imageid=167750&Page=1&Keywords=keyd&SearchType=Basic KEYD-AM exterior photo, 1953, from The Minnesota Historical Society] *[http://www.twincitiesradioairchecks.com/ TwinCitiesRadioAirchecks.com Recordings of KDIZ predecessor, KQRS, and other Twin Cities radio stations] *[http://www.radiotapes.com/KQRS/KEYD-AM_1949.pdf KEYD 1949 promotional station profile] *[http://radiotapes.com/documents/TheHistoryofWDGY-AM.pdf University of Minnesota 1970 thesis on the history of WDGY at radiotapes.com, page 67] *[http://www.pavekmuseum.org/HOF_Gallery/images/tvchrontc.htm Historical reference to KEYD-AM and TV ''Pavek Museum Of Broadcasting''] *[http://www.davidgleason.com/Broadcasting_Yearbook_Summary_Page.htm Broadcasting Yearbooks 1949-1965] *[http://svartifoss2.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/ws.exe/prod/cdbs/pubacc/prod/call_hist.pl?Facility_id=35504&Callsign=KDIZ Station's call sign changes at FCC database] *[http://twincities.bizjournals.com/twincities/stories/2004/04/26/daily7 Radio Aahs receives $12 million payment from ABC, Disney] {{Minneapolis-St. Paul Radio}} {{Salem Media Group}} {{News/Talk Radio Stations in Minnesota}} [[Category:News and talk radio stations in the United States]] [[Category:Radio stations in Minnesota]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1948]] [[Category:1948 establishments in Minnesota]] [[Category:Salem media properties]] [[Category:Business talk radio stations]] [[Category:Business media in the United States]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = Keystone Bank Limited | logo = keystonebank-logo.png | type = [[Private company|Private]] | industry = [[Banking]] | foundation = 2011 | location = [[Victoria Island, Lagos]], [[Lagos State]], Nigeria | key_people = '''Umaru H. Modibbo'''
[[Chairman]]
'''OBEAHON OHIWEREI'''
[[Managing Director]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]]{{cite web|url=http://www.keystonebankng.com/ourpeople.php|title=About : Keystone Bank - Convenience & Reliability|first=Ikpeme|last=James|website=Keystonebankng.com|accessdate=15 October 2017}} | products = [[Loans]], [[Credit Card]]s, [[Savings]], [[Investments]], [[Mortgages]] | revenue = | assets = US$1.916 billion (NGN:307.5 billion){{cite web|url=http://www.keystonebankng.com/2012AnnualReport/4.%20FINANCIALS%20pages%2051%20to%2073.pdf|title=December 2012 Financial Statement|website=Keystonebankng.com|accessdate=15 October 2017}} | num_employees = | homepage = [http://www.keystonebankng.com/ Homepage] }} '''Keystone Bank Limited''', commonly referred to as '''Keystone Bank''', is a [[commercial bank]] in [[Nigeria]]. The bank is one of the commercial banks licensed by the [[Central Bank of Nigeria]], the national banking regulator.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cenbank.org/Supervision/Inst-DM.asp|title=Central Bank of Nigeria {{!}} Commercial Banks|website=Cenbank.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-29}} ==Overview== Keystone Bank offers banking services to large corporations, public institutions, small to medium enterprises (SMEs) and individuals. The bank is a large financial services provider in [[Nigeria]]. {{asof|December 2012}}, the bank's total assets were valued at US$1.916 billion (NGN:307.5 billion), with shareholders' equity valued at about US$213.3 million (NGN:34.23 billion).{{cite web|url=http://www.keystonebankng.com/2012AnnualReport/4.%20FINANCIALS%20pages%2051%20to%2073.pdf|title=Audited December 2012 Financial Statement|website=Keystonebankng.com|accessdate=15 October 2017}} ==History== On Friday 5 August 2011, Keystone Bank Limited was issued a commercial banking license by the [[Central Bank of Nigeria]] (CBN). On the same day, CBN revoked the banking license of [[Bank PHB]]. Keystone Bank assumed the assets and some liabilities of the now defunct Bank PHB.{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201108060011.html|title=Nigeria: Afribank, Spring Bank, Bank PHB Nationalised|last=Chima|first=Obinna|date=2011-08-06|work=This Day (Lagos)|access-date=2017-08-29}} On 22 March 2017, Asset Management Company of Nigeria announced that Keystone bank had been sold to investors for 25 billion naira ($81.5 million). It was sold to Sigma Golf-Riverbank consortium.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2017/03/21/finally-amcon-sells-keystone-bank-for-n25bn-to-new-investors/|title=Finally, AMCON Sells Keystone Bank for N25bn to New Investors|last=Editor|first=Online|date=2017-03-21|work=THISDAYLIVE|access-date=2017-04-06|language=en-US}} ==Ownership== The bank is 100% owned by the '''Asset Management Corporation of Nigeria''' (AMCON), an arm of the [[Federal Government of Nigeria]]. The bank is currently owned by Sigma Golf River Bank Consortium after being acquired from the Asset Management Corporation of Nigeria (AMCON) in March 2017. ==Keystone Bank Group== The bank together with its onshore and offshore subsidiaries, constitute the '''Keystone Bank Group'''. The bank's subsidiaries include the following:{{Cite web|url=http://www.keystonebankng.com/informationcentre.php?p=9&mode=content|title=Keystone Bank {{!}} Convenience & Reliability : Information Centre »|last=James|first=Ikpeme|website=Keystonebankng.com|access-date=2017-08-29}} * [[Global Bank Liberia]] - [[Monrovia]], {{flag|Liberia}} * [[Orient Bank]] - [[Kampala]], {{UGA}} * [http://www.keystonebankng.com/customercarede.php?p=12&mode=content Keystone Insurance] - [[Lagos]], {{NGR}} * [http://allafrica.com/stories/201309301130.html?viewall=1 Keystone Bank (Gambia) Limited] - [[Banjul]], {{flag|Gambia}}{{Cite web|url=http://dailynews.gm/africa/gambia/article/bank-phb-taken-over-story-behind-the-story|title=Bank PHB Taken-Over: Story Behind the Story - Daily News from Gambia|website=dailynews.gm|language=en|access-date=2017-08-29}}{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201309301130.html?viewall=1|title=Gambia: Bank PHB Now Keystone Bank|last=Kargbo|first=Osman|date=2013-09-30|work=The Point (Banjul)|access-date=2017-08-29}} ==Branch network== According to its website, the bank maintains a network of over 150 business offices and locations in all the states of [[Nigeria]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.keystonebankng.com/aboutusde.php?p=55&mode=content|title=Keystone Bank {{!}} Convenience & Reliability : Inside Keystone Bank »|last=James|first=Ikpeme|website=Keystonebankng.com|access-date=2017-08-29}} Some of its products offered to the public includes; QuickSave/ QuickSave Plus, Paytime Accounts, Partner Plus, Active Dom/Dom Extra, Growbiz Account, Future Account, NIDA etc. ==Governance== After the sale of the bank by AMCON, the bank is now governed by a Transitional Board.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2017/03/29/keystone-bank-constitutes-transition-board/|title=Keystone Bank Constitutes Transition Board|last=Editor|first=Online|date=2017-03-28|work=THISDAYLIVE|access-date=2017-04-06|language=en-US}} The [[Chairman]] of the [[Board of Directors|Transitional Board]] of Keystone Bank Limited is '''Alhaji Umaru H. Modibbo'''. The [[Managing Director|Acting Managing Director]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of the bank is '''Hafiz Bakare'''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.financialnigeria.com/keystone-bank-appoints-hafiz-bakare-as-acting-chief-executive-officer-news-1203.html|title=Keystone Bank appoints Hafiz Bakare as Acting Chief Executive Officer|website=Financial Nigeria International Limited|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}} There are three other members of the transitional board of directors at the bank. ==See also== * [[List of banks in Nigeria]] * [[Central Bank of Nigeria]] * [[Economy of Nigeria]] * [[Bank PHB]] * [[Orient Bank]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Other sources== * {{Cite news|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/headlines/226699-amcon-names-new-buyers-keystone-bank.html|title=AMCON names new buyers of Keystone Bank - Premium Times Nigeria|date=2017-03-21|work=Premium Times Nigeria|access-date=2017-04-06|language=en-GB}} ==External links== *[http://www.keystonebankng.com/ Homepage of Keystone Bank Limited] *[http://www.cenbank.org/ Website of Central Bank of Nigeria] *[http://www.vanguardngr.com/2011/08/fg-appoints-mds-for-nationalised-banks/ Federal Government Appoints Leaders of Nationalised Banks] *[http://allafrica.com/stories/201208280495.html Interview With Oti Ikomi, Managing Director Keystone Bank In 2012] *[http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/ikeazor-appointed-keystone-bank-md-ceo/137998/ Ikeazor appointed Keystone Bank MD/CEO] *[http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/ikeazor-resumes-as-keystone-bank-ceo/142145/ Ikeazor resumes as Keystone Bank CEO] *[https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2017/03/29/keystone-bank-constitutes-transition-board/ Keystone Bank constitutes Transition Board] [[Category:Banks of Nigeria]] [[Category:Companies of Nigeria]] [[Category:Banks established in 2011]] [[Category:Companies established in 2011]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Nigeria]] [[Category:Economy of Nigeria]] [[Category:Lagos]] [[Category:Victoria Island, Lagos]] [[Category:Companies based in Lagos]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox Minister | name = Khalid bin Mohammad Al Attiyah | image = Khalid bin Mohammad Al Attiyah - 20181113-D-SV709-0201 (31993029468) (cropped).jpg | office = [[Minister of Defense]] | monarch = [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]] | primeminister =[[Abdullah bin Nasser bin Khalifa Al Thani|Abdullah bin Nasser Al Thani]] | predecessor = [[Hamad bin Ali Al Attiyah|Hamad bin Ali Attiyah]] | term_start= 27 January 2016 | term_end= | office1 = [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Qatar)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] | monarch1 = [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]] | primeminister1 =[[Abdullah bin Nasser bin Khalifa Al Thani|Abdullah bin Nasser Al Thani]] | predecessor1= [[Hamad bin Jassim bin Jaber Al Thani|Hamad bin Jassim Al Thani]] | successor1= [[Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani]] | term_start1= 26 June 2013 | term_end1= 27 January 2016 | office2 = Minister of State for Foreign Affairs | monarch2 =[[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]] | primeminister2=[[Hamad bin Jassim bin Jaber Al Thani|Hamad bin Jassim Al Thani]] | predecessor2 = [[Ahmad bin Abdullah Al Mahmoud]] | successor2 = ''Office abolished'' | term_start2= 1 September 2011 | term_end2= 26 June 2013 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1967|3|9|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Doha]] , [[Qatar]] | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | party = | residence = | alma_mater = [[King Faisal Air Academy]]
[[Beirut Arab University]]
[[Cairo University]] | spouse = | nationality = [[Qatari]] | children = | allegiance = {{flagu|Qatar}} | branch = {{flagicon image|Air Force Ensign of Qatar.svg}} [[Qatar Air Force]] | serviceyears = 1987–1995 | website = | footnotes = }} '''Khalid bin Mohammad Al Attiyah''' ({{lang-ar|خالد بن محمد العطية}}, born 9 March 1967) is a Qatari politician who was [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Qatar)|Minister of Foreign Affairs of Qatar]] from June 2013 to January 2016. He has been Minister of State for Defense since January 2016. ==Early life and education== Al Attiyah was born on 9 March 1967.{{cite web|title=Minister of State for International Cooperation |url=http://english.mofa.gov.qa/orgchart.cfm?id=271 |publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs |accessdate=20 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018223726/http://english.mofa.gov.qa/orgchart.cfm?id=271 |archivedate=18 October 2012 |df= }} His family belong to the [[Banu Tamim]] tribe to which the ruling family of Qatar, the [[House of Thani]], also belong.{{cite news|title=The Attiyah Clan|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/QATAR+-+The+Attiyah+Clan.-a0107984424|accessdate=18 August 2013|work=APS Review Gas Market Trends|date=22 September 2003}} His father was the founder of the [[Qatar Armed Forces]]. He received a bachelor's degree in air science from [[King Faisal Air Academy]] in 1987 and also, a law degree from [[Beirut Arab University]] in 1993. He holds a master's degree in public law (1991) and a PhD in law (2006), both of which he received from [[Cairo University]]. ==Career== Al Attiyah started his career as a fighter pilot and joined Qatar's [[Air Force of Qatar|air force]], where he served from 1987 to 1995. He left the air force and established a law firm in 1995.{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.silatech.com/home/about-us/executive-committee/h-e-dr-khalid-bin-mohamed-al-attiyah|publisher=Sila Tech|accessdate=20 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001155401/http://www.silatech.com/home/about-us/executive-committee/h-e-dr-khalid-bin-mohamed-al-attiyah|archivedate=1 October 2012|df=dmy-all}} From 2003 to 2008 he served as the President of the National Committee for Human Rights.{{cite journal|last=Al Arian|first=Laila|title=Arabian Peninsula|journal=Washington Report on Middle East Affairs|date=May 2004|volume=23|issue=4|page=45|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1P3-624707601/arabian-peninsula|accessdate=31 August 2013}} {{Subscription required|via=Questia}} During the same period he also owned a law firm.{{cite book|title=The Glass Palace: Illusions of Freedom and Democracy in Qatar|year=2012|publisher=Algora|location=New York|url=https://www.questia.com/read/121279241/the-glass-palace-illusions-of-freedom-and-democracy|author=Nasser M. Beydoun|author2=Jennifer Baum |accessdate=14 September 2013}}{{Subscription required|via=Questia}} Then he served as the Minister of State for International Cooperation from 2008 to 2011. During his tenure he also served as acting Minister for Business and Trade.{{cite news|title=Khalid bin Mohammad Al Attiyah|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=60867401&privcapId=46986316&previousCapId=878750&previousTitle=NELCO%20LTD|accessdate=20 April 2013|work=Bloomberg}} In 2009, he became a member of [[Silatech]]'s board of trustees. He is also a member of the board of directors and chairman of the executive committee of the Diar company, and a member of the board of directors of the Qatar electricity and water company.{{cite web|title=Speakers |url=http://www.brookings.edu/about/projects/islamic-world/iwf-2012-speakers |work=Brookings Institution |accessdate=20 April 2013 |year=2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130310003657/http://www.brookings.edu/about/projects/islamic-world/iwf-2012-speakers |archivedate=10 March 2013 |df= }} In a [[cabinet reshuffle]] in September 2011, Al Attiyah was appointed as Minister of State for Foreign Affairs in the cabinet led by Prime Minister [[Hamad bin Jassim bin Jaber Al Thani|Hamad bin Jassim Al Thani]].{{cite news|last=Toumi|first=Habib|title=Deputy premier appointed in Qatar limited cabinet reshuffle|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/qatar/deputy-premier-appointed-in-qatar-limited-cabinet-reshuffle-1.870878|accessdate=20 April 2013|newspaper=Gulf News|date=21 September 2011|location=Manama}}{{cite news|title=Qatar’s crown prince reshuffles some cabinet positions, naming new Deputy PM|url=http://dohanews.co/post/10439505068/qatars-crown-prince-reshuffles-some-cabinet-positions|accessdate=20 April 2013|work=Doha News}} On 26 June 2013, Al Attiyah was named as the Minister of Foreign Affairs in a cabinet reshuffle.{{cite news|title=Qatar's new Emir Sheikh Tamim unveils new cabinet|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23071586|accessdate=27 June 2013|work=BBC|date=26 June 2013}} He replaced Hamad bin Jassim Al Thani as foreign minister.{{cite news|last=Aboudi|first=Sami|title=Qatar drops influential prime minister in cabinet reshuffle|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/26/us-qatar-emir-cabinet-reshuffle-idUSBRE95P0YU20130626|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Reuters|date=26 June 2013}} The cabinet is headed by [[Prime Minister of Qatar|Prime Minister]] [[Abdullah bin Nasser bin Khalifa Al Thani|Abdullah bin Nasser Al Thani]].{{cite news|title=Qatar PM replaced in cabinet reshuffle|url=http://www.albawaba.com/news/qatar-pm-replaced-cabinet-reshuffle-502431|accessdate=27 June 2013|work=Albawaba|date=26 June 2013}} In a cabinet reshuffle on 27 January 2016, Al Attiyah was replaced as Minister of Foreign Affairs by [[Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani]].{{cite news|author1=Asa Fitch|author2=Summer Said|title=Qatar Reshuffles Cabinet, Appointing New Foreign and Defense Ministers|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/qatar-reshuffles-cabinet-1453890732|accessdate=28 January 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=27 January 2016|location=Dubai}}{{cite news|title=Qatar emir names new foreign minister in cabinet reshuffle|url=http://www.thenational.ae/world/middle-east/qatar-emir-names-new-foreign-minister-in-cabinet-reshuffle|accessdate=28 January 2016|work=The National|date=27 January 2016|location=Doha}} In the same reshuffle Al Attiyah was appointed as Minister of State for Defense. ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [http://dw.com/p/1GgrL Khalid bin Mohammad Al-Attiya interviewed] by [[Tim Sebastian]] for the [[DW-TV]] program ''[[Conflict Zone (DW series)|Conflict Zone]]'' (21 October 2015) {{commons category}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Attiyah, Khalid bin Mohammad Al}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Beirut Arab University alumni]] [[Category:Cairo University alumni]] [[Category:Foreign ministers of Qatar]] [[Category:Government ministers of Qatar]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Qatari businesspeople]] [[Category:Qatari military personnel]] [[Category:Qatari politicians]]

{{Distinguish|Khoo Kay Kim}} {{Chinese name|Khoo}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[Malay titles|Yang Berbahagia Tan Sri]] | name = Khoo Kay Peng | native_name = 邱繼炳 | native_name_lang = zh-hant | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1939}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation = Businessman | title = Chairman, [[Laura Ashley plc]] | salary = | networth = US$300 million (Forbes, March 2015)
£400 million (FT, February 2014) | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = Pauline Chai (1970–2017; divorced) | children = 5 | parents = | relatives = | module = {{Infobox Chinese|hide=no|child=yes | t = 邱繼炳 | s = 邱继炳 | p = Qiū Jìbǐng | poj = Khu Kèpéng}} }} [[Malay titles|Tan Sri]] '''Khoo Kay Peng''' ({{zh|t=邱繼炳}}; born 1939) is a [[Malaysian Chinese]] businessman. He is the chairman and a major shareholder of [[Laura Ashley plc]], and the owner of [[MUI Group]]. ==Early life== Khoo Kay Peng was born in 1939.{{cite news|last1=Su-Lyn|first1=Boo|title=Daughter backs mum in divorce from tycoon, says dad disapproves of son-in-law’s race|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/daughter-backs-mum-in-divorce-from-tycoon-says-dad-disapproves-of-son-in-la|accessdate=2 March 2015|work=Malay Mail|date=3 November 2014}} ==Career== Khoo was mentored by [[Khoo Teck Puat]], who founded [[Malayan Banking]] in 1960. Khoo joined the new bank and soon became a manager. In 1965, he was seconded to Bank Bumiputra, and quickly rose to a senior position. In his ten years there, he built relationships with [[Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah]], [[Robert Kuok]] and [[Tan Koon Swan]].{{cite book|author=Peter Searle|title=The Riddle of Malaysian Capitalism: Rent-Seekers Or Real Capitalists?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XpuovMTBl2MC&pg=PA197|year=1999|publisher=Asian Studies Association of Australia|isbn=978-0-8248-2053-4|pages=197–}} He left in 1976 to start his own business, developing property in Kuala Lumpur with a loan from Southern Banking, which made him a millionaire. In 1976, he bought a major stake in [[MUI Group]], then a manufacturer of toothbrushes and household utensils, and used it as a vehicle for a series of corporate takeovers, growing MUI to a $91 million pre-tax profit in 1984. He is the owner of [[MUI Group]], a conglomerate which includes "retail, hotel, food and financial-services interests in Asia, Australia, the U.S. and the U.K." according to ''[[Forbes]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/khoo-kay-peng/|title=Khoo Kay Peng|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=9 January 2018}} He also owns 44% of [[Laura Ashley plc]] and serves as its chairman.Jane Croft, 'Divorce Lawyers on alert for end to era of big payouts for life', ''[[Financial Times]]'', 28 February/1 March 2015, p. 2 He is a director of [[Corus Hotels]].Tom Harper, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/judges-anger-adds-to-acrimony-of-500m-divorce-acrimony-of-laura-ashley-boss-khoo-kay-peng-9347762.html Judge’s anger adds to acrimony of £500m divorce acrimony of Laura Ashley boss Khoo Kay Peng], ''[[The Independent]]'', 09 May 2014 He is the 44th richest person in Malaysia, with an estimated wealth of US$300 million according to ''Forbes''. However, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' suggested he was worth an estimated £400 million in February 2014. ==Personal life== Khoo married Pauline Chai in 1970 when Chai was 24 and he was 31, shortly after she won the [[Miss Malaysia]] beauty contest. Chai first became pregnant in 1971, and they have five children—Alfred, Andrew, Angelina, Angeline and Alex.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/poor-little-rich-girl-finds-her-stride|title=Laura Ashley heiress gave up money for love: Poor little rich girl finds her stride|first=|last=hermes|date=6 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=9 January 2018}} He and his wife divorced in 2017 after 47 years together. He resides in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia. His wife resides at [[Rossway]], an estate in [[Hertfordshire]], England.Julian Robinson, [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2774781/Laura-Ashley-tycoon-resumes-court-battle-wife-40-years-hold-400m-divorce-hearing.html Laura Ashley tycoon resumes court battle with wife of more than 40 years over where to hold £400m divorce hearing], ''[[The Daily Mail]]'', 30 September 2014 Their ongoing divorce has led to the revelation of personal details.Press Association, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/sex/divorce/11137535/Millionaire-Laura-Ashley-boss-spent-hours-on-toilet-doing-business.html Millionaire Laura Ashley boss spent "hours" on toilet doing business], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 2 October 2014 Khoo's daughter, Angeline married Jedidiah Francis, a Caribbean-born [[data scientist]] of Indian descent, and he refused to give them blessings to get married, resulting Khoo and his daughter no longer talking to each other.[https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2017/08/02/khoo-kay-peng-daughter-gave-up-inheritance-to-marry-for-love/ I gave up inheritance to marry for love, says Khoo Kay Peng's daughter] ''[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star Online]]'' (12 August 2017). Retrieved 19 November 2017. Khoo insisted that he would not accept Francis as his son-in-law. ==Honours== Commander of the [[Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia#Commander|Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia]] (P.S.M.) (1986){{cite web |url=http://www.istiadat.gov.my/index.php/component/semakanlantikanskp/|title=Semakan Penerima Darjah Kebesaran, Bintang dan Pingat}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Khoo, Kay Peng}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Kuala Lumpur]] [[Category:Malaysian businesspeople]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia]]
